title: ‘Perfect’ lies hiding a dark truth
text:
Our web of lies: How ‘perfect’ profiles hide the ugly truth Maureen Callahan New York Post Our web of lies: How ‘perfect’ profiles hide the ugly truth Maureen Callahan New York Post Kiersten Rickenbach Cerveny with her husband Andrew Cerveny. Picture: Facebook 
THE contrast between her life and death could not be more stark: The beautiful, successful blonde doctor, a married mother of three, found lying in the doorway of a strange apartment building, her underwear stashed in her handbag, dying of a likely drug overdose. 
To her family and friends, Kiersten Rickenbach Cerveny had it all. 
“This was so out of character . . . I know this was atypical,” one said. Facebook's Dislike Button Is Not What You Think 1:21 
Facebook has finally introduced its answer to people?s appeal for a ?dislike? button ? in the form of six new emojis called ?Reactions.? October 9th 2015 /video/video.news.com.au/News/USA/ Facebook's Dislike Button Is Not What You Think Facebook has finally introduced its answer to people?s appeal for a ?dislike? button ? in the form of six new emojis called ?Reactions.? Madison Halloran and the final picture she posted before being found dead. Kiersten and Andrew on their wedding day. Picture: Facebook Kiersten’s death was at odds with her ‘perfect’ life ... Her family may never know what was real and what was fake. 1 of n 
“She was human,” another said. “People forget that because she was so perfect.” 
Even those who didn’t know the 38-year-old New Yorker would likely draw the same conclusion. 
One look at her Facebook page — since renamed “Remembering Kiersten Rickenbach Cerveny”— would have been, until last Sunday, enough to induce envy in almost anyone. Other Stories
